sn3.1:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
sn3.1:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

sn3.1:1.3.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
sn3.1:1.3.eng: Then King Pasenadi of Kosala went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.
sn3.1:1.3.comm: Pasenadi, son of Sañjaya Mahākosala, ruled the nation of Kosala from its capital Sāvatthī until his death shortly before the Buddha. Like the Buddha’s family, he claimed descent from the Solar lineage of Okkāka. He features throughout the Suttas as a well-meaning if sometimes naive ruler. During his realm, Kosala was a flourishing trade center with a vibrant religious life, a center not just for Buddhists but for Vedic brahmins and Jains, as well as local religious customs.

sn3.1:1.4.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho rājā pasenadi kosalo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn3.1:1.4.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha,
sn3.1:1.4.comm: Pasenadi’s polite but not reverential behavior indicates that he is not yet a devotee of the Buddha. This may, in fact, record their first meeting.

sn3.1:1.5.pli: “bhavampi no gotamo anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambuddhoti paṭijānātī”ti?
sn3.1:1.5.eng: “Does the worthy Gotama claim to have awakened to the supreme perfect awakening?”

sn3.1:1.6.pli: “Yañhi taṃ, mahārāja, sammā vadamāno vadeyya ‘anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambuddho’ti, mameva taṃ sammā vadamāno vadeyya.
sn3.1:1.6.eng: “If anyone should rightly be said to have awakened to the supreme perfect awakening, it’s me.

sn3.1:1.7.eng: For, great king, I have awakened to the supreme perfect awakening.”

sn3.1:2.1.pli: “Yepi te, bho gotama, samaṇabrāhmaṇā saṅghino gaṇino gaṇācariyā ñātā yasassino titthakarā sādhusammatā bahujanassa, seyyathidaṃ—
sn3.1:2.1.eng: “Well, there are those ascetics and brahmins who lead an order and a community, and tutor a community. They’re well-known and famous religious founders, deemed holy by many people. That is,
sn3.1:2.1.comm: The six non-Vedic “ascetics” are referred to as “ascetics and brahmins”. Some, such as Kassapa, may in fact have been brahmins, but the term is probably meant as a generic catch-all for “religious practitioners”.

sn3.1:2.2.pli: pūraṇo kassapo, makkhali gosālo, nigaṇṭho nāṭaputto, sañcayo belaṭṭhaputto, pakudho kaccāyano, ajito kesakambalo;
sn3.1:2.2.eng: Pūraṇa Kassapa, the bamboo-staffed ascetic Gosāla, the Jain ascetic of the Ñātika clan, Sañjaya Belaṭṭhiputta, Pakudha Kaccāyana, and Ajita of the hair blanket.
sn3.1:2.2.comm: The sequence of names here differs from the usual (DN 2:2.2). We have met four of these already in SN 2.30, which gives a summary of their teachings. As for the remaining two, Sañjaya’s method of radical avoidance is taught at DN 2:32.2, while Ajita’s materialistic denial of merit is at DN 2:23.2.

sn3.1:2.3.pli: tepi mayā ‘anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambuddhoti paṭijānāthā’ti puṭṭhā samānā anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambuddhoti na paṭijānanti.
sn3.1:2.3.eng: I also asked them whether they claimed to have awakened to the supreme perfect awakening, but they made no such claim.

sn3.1:2.4.pli: Kiṃ pana bhavaṃ gotamo daharo ceva jātiyā navo ca pabbajjāyā”ti?
sn3.1:2.4.eng: So why do you, given that you’re so young in age and newly gone forth?”

sn3.1:3.1.pli: “Cattāro kho me, mahārāja, daharāti na uññātabbā, daharāti na paribhotabbā.
sn3.1:3.1.eng: “Great king, these four things should not be looked down upon or disparaged because they are young.

sn3.1:3.3.pli: Khattiyo kho, mahārāja, daharoti na uññātabbo, daharoti na paribhotabbo.

sn3.1:3.4.pli: Urago kho, mahārāja, daharoti na uññātabbo, daharoti na paribhotabbo.

sn3.1:3.5.pli: Aggi kho, mahārāja, daharoti na uññātabbo, daharoti na paribhotabbo.

sn3.1:3.6.pli: Bhikkhu, kho, mahārāja, daharoti na uññātabbo, daharoti na paribhotabbo.

sn3.1:3.7.pli: Ime kho, mahārāja, cattāro daharāti na uññātabbā, daharāti na paribhotabbā”ti.
sn3.1:3.7.eng: These four things should not be looked down upon or disparaged because they are young.”

sn3.1:4.1.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

sn3.1:4.2.pli: Idaṃ vatvāna sugato athāparaṃ etadavoca satthā:
sn3.1:4.2.eng: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:

sn3.1:6.1.eng: For it’s possible that that lord of mankind,

sn3.1:6.2.eng: as aristocrat, will gain the throne.

sn3.1:6.3.eng: And in his anger he’ll execute a royal punishment,

sn3.1:6.6.eng: for the sake of your own life.

sn3.1:7.3.eng: a man should not look down on it

sn3.1:7.4.eng: or despise it for its youth.

sn3.1:8.2.eng: the serpent of fiery breath glides along.
sn3.1:8.2.comm: This is an allusion to the venomous bite, tejas having roots in both “sharp” and “fiery”. This metaphor is the origin of the dragon’s fiery breath. For a fiery dragon defeated by the Buddha, whose flames are even more multi-colored, see Kd 1:15.1.1. For a dragon who shape-shifted to seem like a human, see Kd 1:63.1.1.

sn3.1:8.3.eng: It lashes out and bites the fool,

sn3.1:8.6.eng: for the sake of your own life.

sn3.1:9.1.eng: A fire devours a huge amount,

sn3.1:9.2.eng: a conflagration with a blackened trail.

sn3.1:9.3.eng: A man should not look down on it

sn3.1:10.3.eng: It’ll lash out and burn the fool,

sn3.1:10.6.eng: for the sake of your own life.

sn3.1:11.1.eng: When a forest is burned by fire,

sn3.1:11.2.eng: a conflagration with a blackened trail,

sn3.1:11.3.eng: the shoots will spring up there again,

sn3.1:11.4.eng: with the passing of the days and nights.

sn3.1:12.1.eng: But if a mendicant endowed with ethics

sn3.1:12.3.eng: you’ll have no children or livestock,

sn3.1:12.4.eng: nor will your heirs find wealth.

sn3.1:12.6.comm: Indian legends are rife with ascetics who seek vengeance by means of deadly curses for slights real or imagined (eg. Snp 5.1:8.1, MN 56:13.27, MN 93:18.15). A true Buddhist mendicant, on the other hand, bears any slight or grievance with patience and loving-kindness, per the “simile of the saw” (MN 21:20.1, MN 28:24.3). It is, ironically, due to the very perfection of their virtue that any harmful deed done against them reaps a painful karmic result.

sn3.1:13.6.eng: and a mendicant endowed with ethics.”

sn3.1:14.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, rājā pasenadi kosalo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn3.1:14.1.eng: When this was said, King Pasenadi of Kosala said to the Buddha,

sn3.1:14.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhante, nikkujjitaṃ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṃ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṃ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṃ dhāreyya: ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti; evamevaṃ bhagavatā anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.
sn3.1:14.3.eng: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, the Buddha has made the teaching clear in many ways.

sn3.1:14.4.pli: Esāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavantaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.
sn3.1:14.4.eng: I go for refuge to the Buddha, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
sn3.1:14.4.comm: This marks the point at which Pasenadi becomes a follower of the Buddha. The Buddha persuaded him, not through talk on profound philosophy or deep meditation, but with practical advice that is useful for him as a ruler.

sn3.1:14.5.pli: Upāsakaṃ maṃ, bhante, bhagavā dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gatan”ti.
sn3.1:14.5.eng: From this day forth, may the Buddha remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”

sn3.10:1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena raññā pasenadinā kosalena mahājanakāyo bandhāpito hoti, appekacce rajjūhi appekacce andūhi appekacce saṅkhalikāhi.
sn3.10:1.1.eng: Now at that time a large group of people had been put in shackles by King Pasenadi of Kosala—some in ropes, some in manacles, some in chains.
sn3.10:1.1.comm: This story is expanded in Ja 201, where it is said that they were a gang of highwaymen and murderers.

sn3.10:2.1.pli: Atha kho sambahulā bhikkhū pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya sāvatthiṃ piṇḍāya pavisiṃsu.
sn3.10:2.1.eng: Then several mendicants robed up in the morning and, taking their bowls and robes, entered Sāvatthī for alms.

sn3.10:2.2.pli: Sāvatthiyaṃ piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkantā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
sn3.10:2.2.eng: Then, after the meal, when they returned from almsround, they went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what was happening.

sn3.10:2.3.pli: “idha, bhante, raññā pasenadinā kosalena mahājanakāyo bandhāpito, appekacce rajjūhi appekacce andūhi appekacce saṅkhalikāhī”ti.

sn3.10:3.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imā gāthāyo abhāsi:
sn3.10:3.1.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha recited these verses:

sn3.10:4.1.eng: “The attentive say that shackle is not strong

sn3.10:4.2.eng: that’s made of iron, wood, or knots.

sn3.10:4.4.eng: concern for your partners and children:

sn3.10:5.1.eng: this, say the attentive, is a strong shackle

sn3.10:5.2.eng: dragging the indulgent down, hard to escape.

sn3.10:5.3.eng: Having cut this one too they go forth,

sn3.10:5.4.eng: unconcerned, having given up sensual pleasures.”

sn3.11:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati pubbārāme migāramātupāsāde.
sn3.11:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in the stilt longhouse of Migāra’s mother in the Eastern Monastery.
sn3.11:1.1.comm: The same narrative introduces different verses at Ud 6.2. | After the Jetavana, this was the best-known monastery in Sāvatthī. It was offered by the lady Visākhā, known as Migāra’s mother.

sn3.11:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito bahidvārakoṭṭhake nisinno hoti.
sn3.11:1.2.eng: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of retreat and sat outside the gate.

sn3.11:1.3.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
sn3.11:1.3.eng: Then King Pasenadi of Kosala went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side.

sn3.11:2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena satta ca jaṭilā satta ca nigaṇṭhā satta ca acelakā satta ca ekasāṭakā satta ca paribbājakā parūḷhakacchanakhalomā khārivividhamādāya bhagavato avidūre atikkamanti.
sn3.11:2.1.eng: Now at that time seven matted-hair ascetics, seven Jain ascetics, seven naked ascetics, seven one-cloth ascetics, and seven wanderers passed by not far from the Buddha. Their armpits and bodies were hairy, and their nails were long; and they carried their pack with shoulder-poles.
sn3.11:2.1.comm: “Matted-hair ascetics” (jaṭilā) were Vedic ascetics practicing bathing and worshiping the sacred flame (Ud 1.9; see note on MN 40:5.10). | “Jain ascetics” (nigaṇṭhā) were followers of Mahāvīra. The next two types might be the two main subsets of Jains: the Digambara were “naked ascetics” (acelakā), while Śvetāmbara were “one-cloth ascetics” (see AN 6.57:4.1). However, the suttas usually seem to mean the Ājīvakas when they speak of naked ascetics. | “Wanderers (paribbājakā) were homeless religious renunciates—male or female—who wandered seeking alms (see note on DN 1:1.1.3). | For khāri (“pack”) see also SN 7.9:14.1.

sn3.11:2.2.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo uṭṭhāyāsanā ekaṃsaṃ uttarāsaṅgaṃ karitvā dakkhiṇajāṇumaṇḍalaṃ pathaviyaṃ nihantvā yena te satta ca jaṭilā satta ca nigaṇṭhā satta ca acelakā satta ca ekasāṭakā satta ca paribbājakā tenañjaliṃ paṇāmetvā tikkhattuṃ nāmaṃ sāvesi:
sn3.11:2.2.eng: Then King Pasenadi got up from his seat, arranged his robe over one shoulder, knelt with his right knee on the ground, raised his joined palms toward those various ascetics, and pronounced his name three times:

sn3.11:2.3.eng: “Sirs, I am Pasenadi, king of Kosala! …

sn3.11:2.4.eng: I am Pasenadi, king of Kosala!”

sn3.11:3.1.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo acirapakkantesu tesu sattasu ca jaṭilesu sattasu ca nigaṇṭhesu sattasu ca acelakesu sattasu ca ekasāṭakesu sattasu ca paribbājakesu yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho rājā pasenadi kosalo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn3.11:3.1.eng: Then, soon after those ascetics had left, King Pasenadi went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,

sn3.11:3.2.pli: “ye te, bhante, loke arahanto vā arahattamaggaṃ vā samāpannā ete tesaṃ aññatarā”ti.
sn3.11:3.2.eng: “Sir, these are among those in the world who are perfected or who are on the path to perfection!”
sn3.11:3.2.comm: This sentence is phrased as a statement in all editions here. It is also a statement in the parallel passage at Ud 6.2:4.2, except the PTS edition, where it is a question. The commentary in both places confirms it is meant as a statement (“ime arahanto”ti vutte). Pasenadi is testing the Buddha.

sn3.11:4.1.pli: “Dujjānaṃ kho etaṃ, mahārāja, tayā gihinā kāmabhoginā puttasambādhasayanaṃ ajjhāvasantena kāsikacandanaṃ paccanubhontena mālāgandhavilepanaṃ dhārayantena jātarūparajataṃ sādiyantena: ‘ime vā arahanto, ime vā arahattamaggaṃ samāpannā’ti.
sn3.11:4.1.eng: “Great king, as a layman enjoying sensual pleasures, living at home with your children, using sandalwood imported from Kāsi, wearing garlands, fragrance, and makeup, and accepting gold and currency, it’s hard for you to know who is perfected or on the path to perfection.

sn3.11:5.1.pli: Saṃvāsena kho, mahārāja, sīlaṃ veditabbaṃ. Tañca kho dīghena addhunā, na ittaraṃ; manasikarotā, no amanasikarotā; paññavatā, no duppaññena.
sn3.11:5.1.eng: You can get to know a person’s ethics by living with them. But only after a long time, not casually; only when attentive, not when inattentive; and only by the wise, not the witless.

sn3.11:5.2.pli: Saṃvohārena kho, mahārāja, soceyyaṃ veditabbaṃ. Tañca kho dīghena addhunā, na ittaraṃ; manasikarotā, no amanasikarotā; paññavatā, no duppaññena.
sn3.11:5.2.eng: You can get to know a person’s purity by dealing with them. …

sn3.11:5.3.pli: Āpadāsu kho, mahārāja, thāmo veditabbo. So ca kho dīghena addhunā, na ittaraṃ; manasikarotā, no amanasikarotā; paññavatā, no duppaññena.
sn3.11:5.3.eng: You can get to know a person’s resilience in times of trouble. …

sn3.11:5.4.pli: Sākacchāya, kho, mahārāja, paññā veditabbā. Sā ca kho dīghena addhunā, na ittaraṃ; manasikarotā, no amanasikarotā; paññavatā, no duppaññenā”ti.
sn3.11:5.4.eng: You can get to know a person’s wisdom by discussion. But only after a long time, not casually; only when attentive, not when inattentive; and only by the wise, not the witless.”

sn3.11:6.2.eng: how well said this was by the Buddha. …

sn3.11:6.3.pli: ‘dujjānaṃ kho etaṃ, mahārāja, tayā gihinā kāmabhoginā puttasambādhasayanaṃ ajjhāvasantena kāsikacandanaṃ paccanubhontena mālāgandhavilepanaṃ dhārayantena jātarūparajataṃ sādiyantena:

sn3.11:6.4.pli: “ime vā arahanto, ime vā arahattamaggaṃ samāpannā”ti.

sn3.11:6.5.pli: Saṃvāsena kho, mahārāja, sīlaṃ veditabbaṃ. Tañca kho dīghena addhunā, na ittaraṃ; manasikarotā, no amanasikarotā; paññavatā, no duppaññena.

sn3.11:6.6.pli: Saṃvohārena kho, mahārāja, soceyyaṃ veditabbaṃ. Tañca kho dīghena addhunā, na ittaraṃ; manasikarotā, no amanasikarotā; paññavatā, no duppaññena.

sn3.11:6.7.pli: Āpadāsu kho, mahārāja, thāmo veditabbo. So ca kho dīghena addhunā, na ittaraṃ; manasikarotā, no amanasikarotā; paññavatā, no duppaññena.

sn3.11:6.8.pli: Sākacchāya kho, mahārāja, paññā veditabbā. Sā ca kho dīghena addhunā, na ittaraṃ; manasikarotā, no amanasikarotā; paññavatā, no duppaññenā’ti.

sn3.11:7.1.pli: Ete, bhante, mama purisā carā ocarakā janapadaṃ ocaritvā āgacchanti.
sn3.11:7.1.eng: Sir, these are my spies, my undercover agents returning after spying on the country.
sn3.11:7.1.comm: The use of ascetics for spies (cara), which is still common today, is detailed by Kauṭilya in his Arthaśāstra. Those seeking a job can imitate bald (muṇḍa) or matted-hair (jaṭila) ascetics, pretending to live on a handful of greens but secretly eating what they like (as here). Other fake ascetics or spies disguised as merchants then acclaim them to build reputation (as Pasenadi here). When people seek prophecies, he foretells that those loyal to the king shall prosper and those who oppose him will suffer. The king’s minister then ensures that such prophecies come true (1.11.13, 1.13.15). Female mendicants are especially useful for manipulating the wives of officials (5.1.19, 5.1.50, 12.2.20), or officials regarding their wives (11.1.52). Ascetic spies are taught to manipulate loyalties with morality tales (1.14) and to fool enemy kings by faking magical powers (13.2; cp. Devadatta using magic to seduce Ajātasattu at Kd 17:2.1.1). They conduct assassinations by tricking targets into consuming poisons in the guise of a ritual (5.1.33) or love-potions (11.1.40), or he may first instigate rape, then accuse the rapist (11.1.48). Princes may also don the guise of such ascetics in order to escape a coup, while forest ascetics misdirect pursuers (7.17.50). Such spies earn a solid middle income comparable to soldiers, superintendents, teachers, or accountants (5.3.22–3).

sn3.11:7.2.pli: Tehi paṭhamaṃ ociṇṇaṃ ahaṃ pacchā osāpayissāmi.
sn3.11:7.2.eng: I shall later make use of what they first spied out.
sn3.11:7.2.comm: Readings for osāpayissāmi are highly uncertain, and the sentence may be corrupt. Udāna commentary glosses paṭipajjissāmi karissāmi, which suggests Sanskrit apāśri, “employ, practice, use”.

sn3.11:7.3.pli: Idāni te, bhante, taṃ rajojallaṃ pavāhetvā sunhātā suvilittā kappitakesamassū odātavatthā pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappitā samaṅgībhūtā paricāressantī”ti.
sn3.11:7.3.eng: Now—when they have rinsed off the dust and dirt, and are nicely bathed and anointed, with hair and beard dressed, and dressed in white—they will amuse themselves, supplied and provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation.”

sn3.11:8.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imā gāthāyo abhāsi:
sn3.11:8.1.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha recited these verses:

sn3.11:9.1.eng: “It’s not easy to know a man by his appearance.

sn3.11:9.2.eng: You shouldn’t trust them at first sight.

sn3.11:9.3.eng: For undisciplined men live in this world

sn3.11:10.1.eng: Like a fake earring made of clay,

sn3.11:10.2.eng: like a copper halfpenny covered with gold,

sn3.11:10.3.eng: they live hidden in the world,

sn3.12:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena pañcannaṃ rājūnaṃ pasenadipamukhānaṃ pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappitānaṃ samaṅgībhūtānaṃ paricārayamānānaṃ ayamantarākathā udapādi:
sn3.12:1.2.eng: Now at that time five kings headed by Pasenadi were amusing themselves, supplied and provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation, and this discussion came up among them:
sn3.12:1.2.comm: The five kings are not identified.

sn3.12:1.5.eng: “Sights are the best of sensual pleasures!”

sn3.12:1.14.pli: Yato kho te rājāno nāsakkhiṃsu aññamaññaṃ saññāpetuṃ.
sn3.12:1.14.eng: Since those kings were unable to persuade each other,

sn3.12:2.1.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo te rājāno etadavoca:

sn3.12:2.2.pli: “āyāma, mārisā, yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamissāma; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ etamatthaṃ paṭipucchissāma.
sn3.12:2.2.eng: “Come, good fellows, let’s go to the Buddha and ask him about this.
sn3.12:2.2.comm: This term, usually used by gods of the Buddha, is here used among kings to indicate equal status (see SN 1.1:1.4 and note).

sn3.12:2.3.pli: Yathā no bhagavā byākarissati tathā naṃ dhāressāmā”ti.
sn3.12:2.3.eng: As he answers, so we’ll remember it.”

sn3.12:2.4.pli: “Evaṃ, mārisā”ti kho te rājāno rañño pasenadissa kosalassa paccassosuṃ.

sn3.12:3.1.pli: Atha kho te pañca rājāno pasenadipamukhā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho rājā pasenadi kosalo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn3.12:3.1.eng: Then those five kings headed by Pasenadi went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. King Pasenadi reported their conversation to the Buddha, and said,

sn3.12:3.2.pli: “idha, bhante, amhākaṃ pañcannaṃ rājūnaṃ pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappitānaṃ samaṅgībhūtānaṃ paricārayamānānaṃ ayamantarākathā udapādi:

sn3.12:3.14.pli: Kiṃ nu kho, bhante, kāmānaṃ aggan”ti?
sn3.12:3.14.eng: “Sir, what’s the best of sensual pleasures?”

sn3.12:4.1.pli: “Manāpapariyantaṃ khvāhaṃ, mahārāja, pañcasu kāmaguṇesu agganti vadāmi.
sn3.12:4.1.eng: “Great king, which kind of sensual stimulation is best is defined by which is most agreeable, I say.
sn3.12:4.1.comm: The Buddha could have simply rejected out of hand the idea that this was a worthwhile question. Instead, he educates the kings by proposing an analytical approach based in a psychology of empathy, encouraging the kings to remember that other people have different yet valid experiences.

sn3.12:4.2.pli: Teva, mahārāja, rūpā ekaccassa manāpā honti, teva rūpā ekaccassa amanāpā honti.
sn3.12:4.2.eng: The very same sights that are agreeable to some are disagreeable to others.

sn3.12:4.3.pli: Yehi ca yo rūpehi attamano hoti paripuṇṇasaṅkappo, so tehi rūpehi aññaṃ rūpaṃ uttaritaraṃ vā paṇītataraṃ vā na pattheti.
sn3.12:4.3.eng: When you’re happy with certain sights, as you’ve got all you wished for, you don’t want any other sight that’s better or finer.

sn3.12:4.4.eng: For you, those sights are perfect

sn3.12:5.1.pli: Teva, mahārāja, saddā ekaccassa manāpā honti, teva saddā ekaccassa amanāpā honti.

sn3.12:5.2.pli: Yehi ca yo saddehi attamano hoti paripuṇṇasaṅkappo, so tehi saddehi aññaṃ saddaṃ uttaritaraṃ vā paṇītataraṃ vā na pattheti.

sn3.12:6.1.pli: Teva, mahārāja, gandhā ekaccassa manāpā honti, teva gandhā ekaccassa amanāpā honti.

sn3.12:6.2.pli: Yehi ca yo gandhehi attamano hoti paripuṇṇasaṅkappo, so tehi gandhehi aññaṃ gandhaṃ uttaritaraṃ vā paṇītataraṃ vā na pattheti.

sn3.12:7.1.pli: Teva, mahārāja, rasā ekaccassa manāpā honti, teva rasā ekaccassa amanāpā honti.

sn3.12:7.2.pli: Yehi ca yo rasehi attamano hoti paripuṇṇasaṅkappo, so tehi rasehi aññaṃ rasaṃ uttaritaraṃ vā paṇītataraṃ vā na pattheti.

sn3.12:8.1.pli: Teva, mahārāja, phoṭṭhabbā ekaccassa manāpā honti, teva phoṭṭhabbā ekaccassa amanāpā honti.
sn3.12:8.1.eng: touches that are agreeable to some are disagreeable to others.

sn3.12:8.2.pli: Yehi ca yo phoṭṭhabbehi attamano hoti paripuṇṇasaṅkappo, so tehi phoṭṭhabbehi aññaṃ phoṭṭhabbaṃ uttaritaraṃ vā paṇītataraṃ vā na pattheti.
sn3.12:8.2.eng: When you’re happy with certain touches, as you’ve got all you wished for, you don’t want any other touch that’s better or finer.

sn3.12:8.3.eng: For you, those touches are perfect

sn3.12:9.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena candanaṅgaliko upāsako tassaṃ parisāyaṃ nisinno hoti.
sn3.12:9.1.eng: Now at that time the lay follower Candanaṅgalika was sitting in that assembly.

sn3.12:9.2.pli: Atha kho candanaṅgaliko upāsako uṭṭhāyāsanā ekaṃsaṃ uttarāsaṅgaṃ karitvā yena bhagavā tenañjaliṃ paṇāmetvā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn3.12:9.2.eng: Then he got up from his seat, arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and said,

sn3.12:9.3.eng: “I feel inspired to speak, Blessed One! I feel inspired to speak, Holy One!”

sn3.12:9.4.eng: “Then speak as you feel inspired,” said the Buddha.

sn3.12:10.1.pli: Atha kho candanaṅgaliko upāsako bhagavato sammukhā tadanurūpāya gāthāya abhitthavi:
sn3.12:10.1.eng: Then the lay follower Candanaṅgalika extolled the Buddha in his presence with an appropriate verse:
sn3.12:10.1.comm: Candanaṅgalika is unknown elsewhere. The same verse, with a similar outcome, is spoken by the brahmin Piṅgīyānī at AN 5.195:3.1.

sn3.12:11.2.eng: that blooms at daybreak, its fragrance unfaded—

sn3.12:11.3.comm: Aṅgīras was one of the Vedic sages and the Aṅgīrasas are his descendants. They were priestly poets who assisted Indra in freeing the cows from the Vala cave, thus ushering in the dawn. Aṅgīras is regarded as the pravara or revered ancestor of the Gotama clan. Both names are associated with light: aṅgīrasa shares a root and is often synonymous with agni (“fire”), while gotama means “light dispelling dark”.

sn3.12:11.4.eng: bright as the sun in the sky!”

sn3.12:12.1.pli: Atha kho te pañca rājāno candanaṅgalikaṃ upāsakaṃ pañcahi uttarāsaṅgehi acchādesuṃ.
sn3.12:12.1.eng: Then those five kings clothed Candanaṅgalika with five upper robes.

sn3.12:12.2.pli: Atha kho candanaṅgaliko upāsako tehi pañcahi uttarāsaṅgehi bhagavantaṃ acchādesīti.
sn3.12:12.2.eng: And Candanaṅgalika in turn endowed the Buddha with those robes.
